questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: Which technique is used to identify auto antibodies? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect immunofluorescence

 

  • Indirect immunofluorescence is a technique commonly used for the detection of autoantibodies. It involves applying the patient's serum to a substrate that expresses the antigen(s) of interest. If autoantibodies are present, they bind to these antigens. Then another anti-human antibody is added to amplify the response generated. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Immunofluorescence: Used for tissue-bound antibodies where the patient's tissues are stained directly to detect deposits of immunoglobulins or complement.

 

Option B. ELISA: Mainly used for quantifying serum levels of specific antibodies against predefined antigens.

 

Option D. FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization): Used for identifying chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations rather than detecting antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect immunofluorescence allows for the detection of circulating autoantibodies in patient serum by using antigen-expressing substrates, making it a critical tool for diagnosing various autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

choices.text: Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presents to the emergency department with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and confusion. On examination, the child appears dehydrated and is breathing rapidly. Laboratory tests reveal a blood glucose level of 400 mg/dl and blood gas analysis is indicative of acidosis. Initial treatment with intravenous fluids has been started. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is an acute, life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus that typically requires IV fluids and insulin administration to correct hyperglycemia and halt ketogenesis. According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour. 

Other options:

Option B. Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: According to new guidelines, bolus dose of insulin is not used for treatment of DKA particularly in children as it increases the risk of cerebral edema in many children.

 

Option A. Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin infusion is an essential part of DKA management, according to new guidelines, it's typically given one hour after the adminsitration of IV fluids.

 

Option D. Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration: This would not address the hyperglycemia and ketosis and is therefore inadequate for the treatment of DKA.

 

Educational Objective:

According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to diagnose Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Brain biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal neurological complication of measles infection that typically occurs 7-13 years after the primary infection. The diagnosis of SSPE is based on clinical features and supporting laboratory findings, and brain biopsy can show histopathological features of SSPE (such as demyelination, gliosis, and intranuclear inclusion bodies), it is:

 

  • Invasive
  • Rarely required
  • Not part of the routine diagnostic workup, due to reliable clinical and laboratory alternatives.

     

Dyken's Diagnostic Criteria for SSPE

 

Major Criteria (Need at least 3 for diagnosis):

  1. Characteristic Clinical History and Presentation
    1. Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration)
    2. Behavioral changes
    3. Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric)
    4. Motor dysfunction or seizures
  2. Characteristic EEG Findings
    1. Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  3. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in CSF
    1. Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  4. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in Serum
    1. Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  5. Brain Biopsy or Histopathology
    1. Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases)
    2. Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required):
      1. History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age
      2. Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
      3. Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions
      4. Progressive neurological decline over months to years
      5. Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
         

Summary:

 

Diagnosis is typically confirmed if at least 3 of the 5 major criteria are fulfilled, especially with the clinical triad, EEG, and elevated CSF antibodies.

 

Brain biopsy is invasive and rarely needed since the diagnosis can be reliably established with less invasive methods mentioned above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG - Incorrect. EEG is a crucial diagnostic tool for SSPE. It typically shows a characteristic pattern with periodic high-amplitude slow-wave complexes that occur every 4-10 seconds, known as Radermecker complexes.

 

Option C. Antibody in CSF - Incorrect. Elevated measles-specific antibodies in CSF are a key diagnostic criterion for SSPE. The CSF shows increased immunoglobulin G (IgG) with oligoclonal bands specific for measles virus.

 

Option D. Antibody in blood - Incorrect. Elevated serum measles antibody titers (typically 1:256 or higher) are an important diagnostic feature of SSPE, reflecting the immune response to persistent measles virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSPE diagnosis relies on clinical features, characteristic EEG patterns, and elevated measles antibodies in both CSF and serum, with brain biopsy being unnecessary for routine diagnosis of this measles complication.

questions.text: Marked structure is connected to which part of basal nuclei (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus striatum

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the substantia nigra, identified by its pigmented appearance. The substantia nigra is a crucial component of the basal nuclei, involved in the regulation of movement.

 

The substantia nigra communicates with the basal nuclei through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is composed of dopaminergic neurons connecting the substantia nigra to the corpus striatum. This pathway plays a significant role in the modulation of motor activities and is notably affected in Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: Incorrect because the thalamus primarily acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and does not directly connect with the substantia nigra in the context of the basal nuclei.

 

Option B. Subthalamic nucleus: Incorrect because while it is a component of the basal nuclei, it is not the primary structure connected to the substantia nigra in the context of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Globus pallidum: Incorrect because the globus pallidum is involved in regulating voluntary movement but does not have the direct nigrostriatal connection as the corpus striatum does with the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra is connected to the corpus striatum through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is essential for motor control.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily known for its facilitatory presynaptic effects in CNS? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Glutamate

 

Explanation:


Glutamate can function as a facilitatory presynaptic neurotransmitter in the central nervous system. When released, glutamate can act on presynaptic receptors to enhance neurotransmitter release. Presynaptic facilitation occurs when the action potential is prolonged and calcium channels remain open for a longer period, resulting in increased neurotransmitter release. In glutamatergic pathways, this facilitation can enhance synaptic transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GABA - GABA primarily functions as an inhibitory neurotransmitter. At presynaptic terminals, GABA typically causes inhibition rather than facilitation. GABA acting on GABAB receptors increases K+ conductance and inhibits Ca2+ influx, reducing neurotransmitter release.
  • Option b. Glycine - Glycine is an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brainstem and spinal cord. Like GABA, glycine acts by increasing Cl- conductance and generally has inhibitory presynaptic effects rather than facilitatory ones.
  • Option d. Aspartate - While aspartate functions as an excitatory neurotransmitter in some pathways (not primary or most common), it has not been established as having significant facilitatory presynaptic effects in comparison to glutamate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Presynaptic facilitation enhances neurotransmitter release through prolongation of action potentials and increased calcium influx, with glutamate playing a key role in this process within excitatory pathways of the central nervous system.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye) in a 10-year-old boy is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisometropic amblyopia

 

 

Anisometropic amblyopia is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case. It occurs when there is a significant difference in refractive error between the two eyes (typically more than 2.5 diopters). In this scenario, the difference is 4 diopters (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other), which exceeds the threshold. This difference can lead to unequal visual inputs during the critical period of visual development, resulting in amblyopia or "lazy eye" in the eye with the higher refractive error.

 

Causes of Amblyopia:

 

  1. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia: Typically occurs if there's a visual obstruction during developmental years, such as congenital cataract. Even after the obstruction (e.g., cataract) is surgically removed, the affected eye may not achieve normal vision due to the lack of proper visual stimuli during a critical period of visual development.
  2. Strabismic Amblyopia: Occurs when one eye deviates away (strabismus) and does not focus in alignment with the other eye, leading the deviated eye to be underused and become 'lazy.'
  3. Anisometropic Amblyopia: Arises from a significant difference in refractive errors between the two eyes, causing one eye to be less used than the other.
  4. Isoametropic (or ametropic) Amblyopia: Both eyes have high refractive errors and have not been corrected during critical developmental years, leading to underdevelopment in visual acuity in both eyes.

 

The primary treatment for amblyopia involves patching the stronger eye. This forces the amblyopic (lazy) eye to work harder, promoting visual development and function. This method is most effective during the early years, aligning with the critical period of visual development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amblyopia:  While this is partially correct, it's the second best answer. Amblyopia is a visual development disorder where an eye fails to achieve normal visual acuity, devoid of any detectable structural issues of the eye.

 

Option C. Malingering:  Incorrect. This refers to intentional feigning or exaggeration of symptoms, which is not suggested by the given clinical scenario.

 

Option D. Refractive errors:  While refractive errors are present, this answer doesn't capture the key issue of the significant difference between the eyes and its potential consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A difference in refractive power between the two eyes of more than 2.5 diopters can lead to anisometropic amblyopia, especially if untreated during the critical period of visual development (up to about 7 years of age)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection is being evaluated for infectivity status. Which of the following markers indicates high infectivity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBeAg

 

Explanation:

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is a marker of viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection. Its presence indicates:

 

  • High levels of viral replication
  • Higher risk of transmission
  • Greater infectivity
  • Usually associated with higher HBV DNA levels
  • Important prognostic marker for complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBc: Indicates current or past HBV infection, but not infectivity

 

Option B. Anti-HBs: Indicates immunity (through vaccination or recovery), not infectivity

 

Option D. HBsAg: Indicates infection, but does not differentiate between high and low infectivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBeAg is a key marker of high viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: Around which structure does the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loop? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Right subclavian artery

 

 

Explanation:

 

The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery. After arising from the vagus nerve in the neck, it winds posteriorly around the first part of the right subclavian artery and then ascends in the tracheo-esophageal groove to reach the larynx. This looping course is due to embryological development - as the heart and great vessels descend during development, they pull the nerves along with them, creating the recurrent course on both sides, but with different looping points.

 

Other Options:

 

Option b. Right axillary artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the axillary artery. The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery beyond the lateral border of the first rib.

 

Option c. Right external carotid artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the external carotid artery. This artery supplies structures of the face and neck.

 

Option d. Right superior thyroid artery - The recurrent laryngeal nerve does not loop around the superior thyroid artery. This is a branch of the external carotid artery that supplies the thyroid gland.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, while the left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of aorta (specifically the ligamentum arteriosum), creating asymmetry in their courses.

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a genetic disorder characterized by significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood. Tendon xanthomas are a common feature of FH. Statins are commonly prescribed to lower LDL cholesterol levels in FH patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is a different condition that affects the breakdown of triglycerides in lipoproteins, not cholesterol metabolism. It does not typically present with tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is a rare genetic disorder that leads to very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. It does not typically present with elevated LDL cholesterol levels or tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is a neurological disorder and is not related to cholesterol metabolism or tendon xanthomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the conditions i.e. tendon xanthomas, high serum cholesterol and LDL levels and statin therapy which is given to inhibit rate limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase of cholesterol biosynthesis indicate that cholesterol is raised in this patient. So, the most probable diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia aka Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia that occur due to deficiency of LDL receptor on liver or Apo B100 mutation.

 

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency or Apo C- II defect cause familial hyperchylomicronemia or Type I hyperlipoproteinemia with raised plasma chylomicrons and TG levels.

 

In Tangier’s disease, there is defect in ABCA1 receptors causing low levels of plasma HDL.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 258

questions.text: Stoss therapy is utilized for the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Vitamin D deficiency rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Stoss therapy refers to the administration of a large single dose or a few divided doses of vitamin D for the rapid correction of vitamin D deficiency. This therapy is specifically designed for treating nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets. It typically involves giving a high dose of vitamin D (typically 300,000-600,000 IU) as either a single dose or divided over a few days.

 

The advantages of Stoss therapy include improved compliance (as it requires fewer doses) and rapid correction of deficiency. After the initial high-dose therapy, maintenance doses of vitamin D are continued to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly useful in situations where compliance with daily supplementation might be challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scurvy - Incorrect. Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and is treated with vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day for 3 months), not high-dose vitamin D therapy.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia - Incorrect. Keratomalacia is a condition resulting from severe vitamin A deficiency affecting the cornea. It requires vitamin A supplementation, not vitamin D. Treatment usually involves 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on day 1, repeated on day 2 and after 2 weeks.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemic rickets - Incorrect. Hypophosphatemic rickets (vitamin D-resistant rickets) is typically hereditary and caused by phosphate wasting, not vitamin D deficiency. It is treated with phosphate supplements and calcitriol, not high-dose vitamin D therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stoss therapy is specifically used for treating vitamin D deficiency rickets with large doses (300,000-600,000 IU) given over a short period, providing rapid correction and improved compliance compared to daily supplementation regimens.

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

Arsenic gets fixed to the bones and gets released from it very slowly over a period of time and thus can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

 

Toxicokinetic of Arsenic:

 

  1. Because of short half-life of arsenic in the blood, arsenic is rapidly cleared from the blood. Hence it is less reliable to detect arsenic poisoning.
  2. After clearing from blood, arsenic gets deposited in almost all the tissues where it is found for prolonged period. However, arsenic does not cross blood brain barrier.
  3. Highest concentration is found in liver (followed by kidney)
  4. Urine becomes positive within 6 hours of poisoning and may continue to be positive for about 2-3 weeks. Urine is better than blood to detect arsenic poisoning.
  5. Arsenic also gets deposited in hair, nails, skin and bones where it remains for a much more prolonged time (even for years) after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in the blood but does not leave detectable residues in skeletal remains.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulphide: Hydrogen sulphide is a gas that affects soft tissues and is not detected in skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus can affect soft tissues but is not typically detected in bones long after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child with a history of vomiting undergoes imaging as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Congenital Pyloric Stenosis


The correct diagnosis is Congenital Pyloric Stenosis. This condition typically presents in infants between 3-6 weeks of age with symptoms of projectile, non-bilious vomiting, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen. The ultrasound image shows a thickened pylorus muscle and a distended stomach, which are characteristic findings of pyloric stenosis. The hypertrophied pyloric muscle obstructs gastric emptying, leading to the clinical symptoms observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition usually presenting at birth with bilious vomiting due to a blockage in the duodenum. It is often associated with a “double bubble” sign on imaging. The condition does not fit the presentation of a 4-week-old with the typical findings seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option C. Annular Pancreas: Annular pancreas is a congenital anomaly where the pancreas encircles the duodenum, potentially causing obstruction. It usually presents with symptoms soon after birth, similar to duodenal atresia, including bilious vomiting. This condition would not show the thickened pylorus seen in the ultrasound provided.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus, often associated with malrotation of the midgut, can present at any age, including the newborn period or later in life. It typically presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and sometimes acute abdominal pain. The ultrasound findings here do not indicate the twisted bowel loops characteristic of volvulus but rather show a thickened pyloric muscle.

 

Educational Objective:


Congenital Pyloric Stenosis is characterized by the hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to projectile, non-bilious vomiting in infants aged 3-6 weeks. Ultrasound is diagnostic, showing a thickened pyloric muscle and a distended stomach, distinguishing it from other causes of vomiting in infancy.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

  • The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Stage 1: Non-blanchable erythema of intact skin. Redness that does not fade when pressure is applied.
  • Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss with exposed dermis. The wound bed is viable, pink or red, and moist.
  • Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss. Subcutaneous fat may be visible, but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed.
  • Stage 4: Full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Exposed or directly palpable fascia, muscle, tendon, ligament, cartilage, or bone in the ulcer.
  • Unstageable: Obscured full-thickness skin and tissue loss. Extent of tissue damage within the ulcer cannot be confirmed because it is obscured by slough or eschar.
  • Deep Tissue Pressure Injury: Persistent non-blanchable deep red, maroon, or purple discoloration.

 

Treatment Focus:

 

  • Patient Optimization: Addressing poor nutrition and managing ongoing medical problems.
  • Preventative Measures: Implementing strategies to prevent further pressure injuries.
  • Debridement: Removing necrotic tissue if appropriate.

 

Given the extensive tissue destruction shown in the image, with damage extending through the muscle layer, the pressure sore is classified as a Stage 4 pressure injury.

questions.text: What is the typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 125 ml/min

 

The Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is a measure of how much blood is filtered by the glomeruli in the kidneys per minute. It is a critical indicator of kidney function. In a healthy adult, the typical GFR is approximately 125 ml/min. This value can vary based on factors such as age, sex, and body size, but 125 ml/min is generally accepted as the normal average for a healthy adult

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) value in a healthy adult is approximately 125 ml/min, reflecting normal kidney function.

questions.text: Which of the following tools is used to determine the rupture of the hymen and whether the rupture is recent or old in rape victims? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Glaister Keene Rod

 

Explanation:

 

The Glaister-keen rod is specially designed for examining the hymen in sexual assault victims. It consists of a glass rod with one end expanded into a globe (1-2.5 cm diameter). When inserted gently behind the hymen, it displays the hymen edges over the glass, allowing small tears and nicks to be visualized clearly by smoothing out folds and indentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gahn Rod - This instrument is not recognized in forensic medicine for hymen examination.

 

Option C. Carm Rod - This is not a valid tool for hymen examination in sexual assault cases.

 

Option D. Cylinder Rod - While rod-shaped instruments may be used in medical examinations, this specific tool is not used for hymen assessment in forensic cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Glaister-keen rod is an essential forensic tool that enables accurate documentation of hymen tears by providing proper visualization of the hymen edges, helping distinguish between recent tears (with sharp, red, bleeding edges) and older injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

In the context of acute inflammation, most plasma proteins, known as acute-phase reactants, typically increase due to the influence of cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-1 (IL-1). These are referred to as positive acute-phase reactants.

 

However, there are certain proteins, called negative acute-phase reactants, that decrease during acute inflammation. Albumin is one such protein. The decrease in albumin during inflammation is thought to help conserve amino acids for the production of more essential proteins needed during the inflammatory response. Additionally, lower albumin levels help to reduce blood viscosity and facilitate the movement of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a well-known positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels significantly increase during inflammation, making it a common marker for detecting inflammation.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute-phase reactant. It increases during inflammation and plays a role in iron metabolism, often contributing to the anemia seen in chronic disease.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin, an iron-storage protein, also acts as a positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels rise during inflammation, reflecting increased storage of iron in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin

 

Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with severe nodulocystic acne involving the face and back, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne, which is the most severe form of acne vulgaris. In grade 4 acne:

 

  • Patients present with deep nodules and cysts
  • Lesions are typically present on face and back
  • Treatment choice is oral isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)
  • Dosage: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day with total cumulative dose of 120-150 mg/kg
  • Isotretinoin requires monitoring of lipid profile and liver function tests.

 

Oral isotretinoin is the treatment of choice for severe nodulocystic acne due to its ability to target all four pathophysiological factors of acne:

 

  1. Reduces sebum production by shrinking sebaceous glands.
  2. Inhibits follicular keratinization, preventing comedone formation.
  3. Exerts anti-inflammatory effects.
  4. Reduces the population of Propionibacterium acnes, the bacteria involved in acne pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone/Steroids

 

  • Systemic steroids are not indicated for routine acne treatment
  • Can actually worsen acne on withdrawal
  • May have role in severe inflammatory acne but not as monotherapy

 

Option C. Topical tretinoin

 

  • Only indicated for grade 1 (comedonal) acne
  • Used along with topical antibiotics in grade 2 acne
  • Insufficient for severe nodulocystic acne

 

Option D. Azithromycin

 

  • Oral antibiotics like azithromycin are used in grade 3 acne
  • Not potent enough for severe nodulocystic lesions
  • Oral Minocycline, Azithromycin and Doxycycline can be used in grade 3 acne

 

Grades of Acne:

 

  1. Grade 1 : Non-inflammatory open and closed comedones. Treated with topical retinoids (Tretinoin, Adapalene).
  2. Grade 2 (Mild inflammatory acne): Presence of papules and mild erythema. Treated with topical retinoids + topical antibiotics (Clindamycin, Nadifloxacin).
  3. Grade 3 (Moderate inflammatory acne): Predominance of pustules. Treated with topical retinoids + oral antibiotics (Minocycline, Azithromycin, Doxycycline).
  4. Grade 4 (Severe nodulocystic acne): Deep, painful nodules and cysts on the face, chest, and back. Treatment of choice: Oral isotretinoin.

 

Educational Objective:


Oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice for grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne vulgaris.
